The content is for educational purposes only and does not guarantee eligibility for naturalization or success in the actual interview, which is not multiple-choice.
This page requires Flash Player version 10.1.52 or higher to understand commands for the naturalization interview.
This page provides information on check processing times.
This H1 tag indicates a section related to "Need Help" within the "LINK-myUSCIS" system. This suggests it's a support or assistance page for users of the myUSCIS platform.

This document outlines citizenship pathways for military family members. Spouses of U.S. service members may qualify for expedited naturalization, either within the U.S. under INA 319(b) if they meet specific criteria including being a lawful permanent resident and residing with their service member spouse stationed abroad, or abroad under INA 319(e)(2) if authorized to accompany their spouse stationed overseas. Children of service members may automatically acquire citizenship under INA 320 or naturalize under INA 322 without travel to the U.S. The document also touches on naturalization for surviving spouses and children of deceased service members, and the general process for spouses adjusting their status, including considerations during service member deployment. It emphasizes contacting the Military Help Line for expedited processing related to PCS orders and notes that requests are reviewed case-by-case.

Since 2002, over 187,000 U.S. service members and veterans have been naturalized. In the last five fiscal years (2020-2024), more than 52,000 service members were naturalized, with FY 2024 seeing a 34% increase to over 16,290 individuals.

The top countries of birth for naturalized service members from FY 2020-2024 were the Philippines, Jamaica, Mexico, Nigeria, and Ghana, accounting for over 38% of cases. The next five countries (Haiti, China, Cameroon, Vietnam, and South Korea) represented an additional 16%.

The median age of naturalizing service members during this period was 27, with 50% falling between 22 and 30 years old. Over 17% were 21 or younger, and nearly 5% were older than 40.

Men constituted 73% of those naturalized between FY 2020 and FY 2024, with a slight increase in the proportion of women over time. The Army, including National Guard and Reserves, accounted for 60% of military naturalizations in this period, while the Coast Guard represented less than 1%.

This section provides immigration information and resources tailored for military members and their families, covering topics such as naturalization through military service, citizenship for family members, survivor benefits, and discretionary options.

This document outlines the process for U.S. military service members and veterans to naturalize and become U.S. citizens through special provisions of the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA). There are two main pathways:

**INA 328:** For those who have served honorably in the U.S. armed forces for at least one year at any time. While some general naturalization requirements apply, others are reduced or waived. Key requirements include being 18 or older, honorable service, providing appropriate service documentation (Form N-426 or discharge papers), demonstrating honorable separation (if not currently serving), being a lawful permanent resident at the time of the interview, meeting certain residence and physical presence rules, English and civics proficiency (unless waived), demonstrating good moral character, and attachment to U.S. constitutional principles.

**INA 329:** For those who served honorably during designated periods of hostilities. This pathway offers greater flexibility, often waiving continuous residence and physical presence requirements. Service members must have served honorably during a designated period of hostility (listed in the document), have appropriate service documentation, and meet specific residency or physical presence criteria at the time of enlistment/induction (e.g., in the U.S., Canal Zone, American Samoa, or on a U.S. public vessel). English and civics proficiency, good moral character, and attachment to U.S. principles are also required, though waivers may apply.

**General Application Process:**

*   **Forms:** File Form N-400, Application for Naturalization. If currently serving, also file Form N-426. If separated, provide discharge documents (DD Form 214, NGB Form 22, etc.). For posthumous citizenship, file Form N-644.
*   **Fees:** Applications under INA 328 and 329 are fee-exempt.
*   **Filing:** Applications can be mailed to a specific USCIS P.O. Box in Chicago or filed online through a USCIS online account.
*   **Biometrics:** Fingerprinting will be required, which can be done using previous prints, through specific procedures abroad, or at an Application Support Center (ASC) in the U.S. (where prior or current military service must be presented).
*   **Interview:** Applicants will have an interview at a USCIS field office to review eligibility and test English and civics knowledge.
*   **Oath of Allegiance:** Upon approval, applicants will take the Oath of Allegiance to become a U.S. citizen. Those applying based on military service during hostilities must complete this process in the U.S.
*   **Assistance:** USCIS liaisons are available on many military installations to help with the application process. A Military Help Line is also available for inquiries.

**Posthumous Citizenship (INA 329A):**

*   For service members who died as a result of injury or disease incurred/aggravated during honorable service in a designated period of hostilities.
*   Form N-644 must be filed within two years of death.
*   Other immigration benefits may be available to surviving family members.

The document also provides links to additional resources, including USCIS Policy Manuals, fact sheets, and study materials for the English and civics tests.

С 27 февраля 2024 года в США действует программа, позволяющая определенным категориям граждан Украины и их близким родственникам, которые уже находились в стране, подать заявку на повторное получение гуманитарного пароля. Эта возможность распространяется на тех, кто получил гуманитарный пароль 11 февраля 2022 года или позднее.

**Основные условия для подачи заявки:**

*   **Статус:** Вы должны быть гражданином Украины (или близким родственником), получившим гуманитарный пароль в США 11 февраля 2022 года или позже.
*   **Причины:** Необходимость продления пароля должна быть обусловлена продолжающимися неотложными гуманитарными причинами или значительной общественной пользой от вашего пребывания.
*   **Соответствие критериям:** Необходимо соответствовать общим критериям для положительного решения по делу.
*   **Физическое присутствие:** Вы должны находиться на территории США.
*   **Соблюдение условий:** Важно, чтобы вы выполнили все условия первоначального гуманитарного пароля.
*   **Проверки:** Вы должны успешно пройти биографическую и биометрическую проверку.

**Процесс подачи:**

*   Для подачи заявки используется **форма I-131 «Заявление на получение проездного документа»**.
*   Подать заявление можно **онлайн** через аккаунт USCIS или **в бумажном виде** по почте.
*   При подаче онлайн необходимо выбрать соответствующую опцию.
*   При подаче в бумажном виде на форме I-131 следует указать "Ukraine RE-PAROLE".
*   Подача онлайн рекомендуется для избежания распространенных ошибок и отслеживания статуса заявки.
*   Запросы на освобождение от уплаты сбора (форма I-912) принимаются **только** при подаче в бумажном виде.

**Разрешение на работу:**

*   В случае одобрения повторного гуманитарного пароля, вы можете подать **форму I-765 «Заявление на получение разрешения на работу»** для получения нового документа о разрешении на работу (EAD) на срок действия пароля.
*   Форму I-765 также можно подать онлайн. **Не подавайте ее до получения одобрения повторного пароля**, иначе заявка может быть отклонена.
*   До получения нового EAD, обновленная форма I-94 (с пометкой "UHP" и датой последнего въезда до 30 сентября 2023 года) может служить подтверждением личности и права на работу в течение 90 дней.

З 27 лютого 2024 року певні категорії громадян України та їхніх найближчих родичів, які перебувають у США, можуть подати заяву на повторне отримання гуманітарного паролю. Це дозволяє їм тимчасово залишатися в країні.

**Хто може подати заявку:**
* Громадяни України та їхні найближчі родичі, які отримали гуманітарний пароль у США 11 лютого 2022 року або пізніше.
* Особи, які фізично перебувають у США.
* Особи, які відповідають критеріям, зокрема мають невідкладні гуманітарні обставини або їхній пароль становить значну суспільну користь.
* Особи, які виконали умови первинного паролю та пройшли перевірку даних.

**Як подати заявку:**
* Подати форму I-131 "Заява про отримання проїзного документа" онлайн або поштою.
* Рекомендується подавати онлайн через обліковий запис USCIS для уникнення помилок.
* У разі подання поштою, на бланку форми I-131 слід написати "Ukraine RE-PAROLE".
* Заявка розглядається Службою громадянства та імміграції США (USCIS) на дискреційній основі.

**Дозвіл на роботу:**
* У разі схвалення заявки на повторний пароль, можна подати форму I-765 "Заява про дозвіл на працевлаштування" для отримання дозволу на роботу (EAD).
* Оновлена форма I-94 може слугувати документом, що підтверджує дозвіл на роботу протягом 90 днів після схвалення повторного паролю.

**Важливо:**
* USCIS враховуватиме триваючі надзвичайні обставини в Україні.
* Детальні інструкції доступні на сторінці "Процес повторного отримання пароля для певних категорій українців".

Starting February 27, 2024, eligible Ukrainian citizens and their immediate family members already in the U.S. can apply for re-parole to continue their temporary stay. This applies to those who were paroled into the U.S. on or after February 11, 2022. Applications will be reviewed on a case-by-case basis for urgent humanitarian reasons or significant public benefit, considering the ongoing extraordinary circumstances in Ukraine.

To be eligible, applicants must be Ukrainian citizens or immediate family members paroled into the U.S. on or after February 11, 2022, demonstrate continued humanitarian need or public benefit, warrant discretionary approval, be physically present in the U.S. as a parolee, have complied with initial parole conditions, and pass background checks.

Applications are submitted using Form I-131, Application for Travel Document, either online or by mail, with supporting documents and the required fee or a fee waiver request. Filing online is encouraged for efficiency.

Upon approval of re-parole, individuals can apply for an Employment Authorization Document (EAD) using Form I-765. Certain parolees with a recent entry date of September 30, 2023, or earlier, and a Form I-94 with "UHP" as the class of admission, may use their I-94 as temporary proof of identity and employment authorization for up to 90 days.

The Supreme Court has lifted a preliminary injunction that had blocked the termination of the parole process for Cubans, Haitians, Nicaraguans, and Venezuelans (CHNV). This means the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) can now proceed with ending parole for individuals under these programs and revoke their associated employment authorization. Affected individuals will be notified through their myUSCIS accounts.

USCIS is pausing the acceptance of Form I-134A, Online Request to be a Supporter and Declaration of Financial Support, until further notice. This pause is a result of the Executive Order "Securing Our Borders" dated January 20, 2025, and is necessary to review all categorical parole processes.

USCIS is implementing a new mail delivery process for Lawful Permanent Residents (LPRs) to receive temporary evidence of their status, known as an ADIT (I-551) stamp. This aims to reduce the need for in-person appointments at field offices.

LPRs who do not have their Green Card or whose Green Card and extension notice have expired while their I-90, I-751, or N-400 application is pending can request this temporary evidence.

To receive the ADIT stamp by mail, LPRs must contact the USCIS Contact Center. An officer will verify their identity, mailing address, and confirm if UPS or FedEx can deliver to that address. If an in-person appointment isn't necessary, USCIS will mail a Form I-94 with the ADIT stamp, DHS seal, and a photo from USCIS systems.

USCIS retains discretion in issuing ADIT stamps, determining their validity (up to one year, unless otherwise specified). However, some LPRs, particularly those with urgent needs, missing photos in USCIS systems, or unconfirmed addresses/identities, will still require in-person appointments. This new process is intended to provide timely evidence of status and free up field office resources.

USCIS is extending the validity of Green Cards for conditional permanent residents who have filed Form I-751 or Form I-829 to remove conditions. This extension is for 48 months beyond the card's expiration date and applies to new filings starting January 11, 2023 (Form I-829) and January 25, 2023 (Form I-751). This change is due to increased processing times for these forms. USCIS will issue updated receipt notices for these filings, which, along with an expired Green Card, will serve as proof of continued status, work authorization, and travel authorization for the 48-month period. Conditional residents planning to travel abroad for a year or more should still file Form I-131 for a reentry permit before departing.

USCIS is reminding employment-based petitioners to ensure they submit the correct filing fees to avoid rejection of their applications. This is particularly important for Forms I-129, I-129CW, and I-140, where fees can vary based on nonprofit or small employer status. The Asylum Program Fee applies to these forms, with discounted rates available for small employers (25 or fewer full-time equivalent employees). Petitioners must accurately determine and document their employee count, including all affiliates and subsidiaries, and follow specific payment guidelines, especially when submitting multiple forms or using credit card payments online. Evidence such as IRS Form 941 or 943 can be used to demonstrate employee numbers, and redaction of salary information is permitted if only supporting fee eligibility.

DHS (Department of Homeland Security) একটি নতুন নিয়ম জারি করেছে যা নিশ্চিত করে যে কিছু সরকারি সুবিধার ব্যবহারকারীদের নাগরিকত্ব বা গ্রিন কার্ড পেতে সমস্যা হবে না। এই নিয়মটি পূর্বের কিছু নীতি পরিবর্তন করে, যা নির্দিষ্ট সরকারি সহায়তাকে "পাবলিক চার্জ" হিসেবে বিবেচনা করত এবং অভিবাসন প্রক্রিয়াকে কঠিন করে তুলত। নতুন নিয়মটি ১৯৯৯ সালের নীতি ফিরিয়ে এনেছে, যা মানবিক স্বাস্থ্য সুবিধা যেমন মেডিকেড এবং পুষ্টি সহায়তা (SNAP) ব্যবহারকারীদের পাবলিক চার্জ হিসেবে গণ্য করবে না। DHS জানিয়েছে যে এই পরিবর্তনটি বৈধ অভিবাসী এবং তাদের পরিবারের সাথে ন্যায্য আচরণ নিশ্চিত করবে। নতুন নিয়মটি কার্যকর হবে ২৩শে ডিসেম্বর, ২০২২ থেকে।
国土安全部 (DHS) 发布了一项关于“公共负担”的最终规则，该规则恢复了对“公共负担”的历史理解，即主要依赖政府维持生计的非公民可能被禁止入境。新规则将不再把某些公共福利，如 Medicaid 和营养援助，纳入公共负担的考量范围，旨在确保合法移民及其家人受到公平和人道的对待。该规则将于 2022 年 12 月 23 日生效，DHS 将更新政策手册并进行公众宣传，以确保规则得到公平一致的应用。

Depatman Sekirite Enteryè (DHS) te pibliye yon nouvo règ pou chaj piblik ki amelyore pwosesis pou detèmine si yon moun ki pa sitwayen kalifye pou sèvis gouvènman yo. Règ la retabli ansyen definisyon "chaj piblik" ki pa konsidere sèvis piblik tankou Medicaid oswa èd alimantè kòm motif pou diskalifikasyon. Sekretè DHS Alejandro Mayorkas te deklare ke aksyon sa a asire tretman jis ak imanitè pou imigran legal yo. Direktè USCIS Ur M. Jaddou te ajoute ke politik sa a trete tout moun avèk respè. Règ la pral antre anvigè 23 desanm 2022, epi li pral ede anpeche moun yo evite sèvis enpòtan.

وزارت امنیت داخلی ایالات متحده (DHS) مقرره نهایی را برای تسهیل دسترسی عادلانه و انسانی به مساعدت های دولتی برای متقاضیان غیرشهروند تصویب کرد. این مقرره تعریف "استفاده از مساعدت های دولتی" را احیا می کند که قبلاً برای چندین دهه اعمال می شد و خدمات دولتی مانند بیمه صحی مدیکید و کمک غذایی را به عنوان معیاری برای عدم دریافت اقامت دائم در نظر نمی گرفت. وزیر امنیت داخلی، آلخاندرو مایورکاس، تاکید کرد که این تصمیم با ارزش های اساسی آمریکا مبنی بر برخورد عادلانه با پناهندگان قانونی و اعضای خانواده های شهروندان آمریکایی همسو است و افراد را به دلیل استفاده از مزایای صحی و سایر خدمات دولتی جریمه نمی کند. این مقرره در 9 سپتامبر 2022 در جریده رسمی فدرال منتشر و از 23 دسامبر 2022 اجرایی خواهد شد. DHS همچنین برنامه های آگاهی عمومی برای جلوگیری از سوء تفاهم در مورد این قانون را راه اندازی خواهد کرد.

미국 국토안보부(DHS)는 2022년 9월 8일, 비시민권자에게 공적부조 심사를 더 명확하고 일관성 있게 적용하는 규정 최종안을 발표했습니다. 이 규정은 과거 수십 년간 시행되어 온 '공적부조' 원칙을 복원하여, 메디케이드나 영양 지원 프로그램과 같은 보조 의료 혜택을 공적부조 기각 요건으로 간주하지 않도록 합니다.

알레한드로 마요르카스 국토안보부 장관은 이번 조치가 합법적 이민자들과 그 가족에게 공정하고 인도적인 대우를 보장하며, 의료 혜택 등으로 인해 불이익을 주지 않을 것이라고 강조했습니다. 우르 자도우 미국 이민국장은 이민 제도에 대한 신뢰 회복과 불필요한 부담 완화를 위한 노력을 지속할 것이라고 덧붙였습니다.

이번 규정은 연방정부 공보에 고시되었으며, 2022년 12월 23일부터 발효됩니다. 주요 변경 사항은 다음과 같습니다.

*   **'공적부조'의 정의 복원:** 2019년 이전과 같이, 메디케이드 또는 영양 지원과 같은 비현금성 혜택은 공적부조 심사 기준에서 제외됩니다.
*   **심사 기준:** 공적부조 수급자가 될 가능성이 있는 비시민권자로 간주되는 기준은 다음과 같습니다:
    *   나이, 건강, 가족 관계, 자산, 재정 상태, 교육 및 기술
    *   재정보증서 (Affidavit of Support)
    *   이전 또는 현재의 보조 소득 보장 (SSI), 빈곤 가구 임시 지원 (TANF) 등 정부 현금 지원 수급 여부
    *   정부 부담 장기 요양 수급 여부
*   **고려하지 않는 혜택:** 신청자가 아닌 다른 가족 구성원이 받은 혜택, SNAP(저소득층 영양 보충 지원 프로그램), CHIP(아동 의료 보험 프로그램), 메디케이드(장기 보호 시설 혜택 제외), 주택 혜택, 전염병 관련 혜택 등은 공적부조 심사 기준에 포함되지 않습니다.

DHS는 새로운 규정의 공정한 적용을 위해 규정 매뉴얼을 마련하고, 대중 홍보 및 참여 유도를 통해 혼란을 최소화할 계획입니다.

गृहभूमि सुरक्षा विभाग (DHS) ले एक नयाँ नियम जारी गरेको छ जसले आप्रवासनमा सार्वजनिक शुल्कको आधारमा गैर-नागरिकहरूलाई कसरी अस्वीकार गरिनेछ भनेर स्पष्ट पार्छ। यो नियमले पूर्व प्रशासनले पूरक स्वास्थ्य लाभहरू जस्तै Medicaid र पोषण सहायतालाई सार्वजनिक शुल्क निर्धारणमा समावेश गर्ने निर्णयलाई उल्टाउँछ। नयाँ नियमले विगत दुई दशकदेखि अवस्थित सार्वजनिक शुल्कको ऐतिहासिक बुझाइलाई पुनर्स्थापित गर्छ, जुन १९९९ को अन्तरिम क्षेत्र निर्देशनमा आधारित छ।

यस नियम अन्तर्गत, गैर-नागरिकलाई सार्वजनिक शुल्कको रूपमा मानिनेछ यदि उनीहरूको जीविकाको लागि सरकारमा निर्भर हुने सम्भावना छ भने। यो निर्धारण उमेर, स्वास्थ्य, पारिवारिक स्थिति, सम्पत्ति, स्रोतसाधन, आर्थिक स्थिति, शिक्षा र सिप जस्ता कारकहरूमा आधारित हुनेछ। समर्थनको शपथ पत्र र केही सरकारी लाभहरूको रसिद पनि विचार गरिनेछ।

DHS ले आवेदक बाहेक परिवारका सदस्यहरूबाट प्राप्त हुने लाभहरू, साथै SNAP, CHIP, Medicaid (दीर्घकालीन संस्थागतकरण बाहेक), र आवास लाभहरू जस्ता गैर-नगद लाभहरूलाई सार्वजनिक शुल्क निर्धारणमा विचार गर्ने छैन।

यो नियम डिसेम्बर २३, २०२२ देखि लागू हुनेछ। DHS ले यस नियमलाई निष्पक्ष र लगातार लागू गर्न नीति नियमावली अद्यावधिक गर्नेछ र जनतालाई यसको बारेमा जानकारी दिन सार्वजनिक पहुँच र संलग्नताहरू सञ्चालन गर्नेछ।

د متحده ایالتونو د کورني امنیت وزارت (DHS) د بهرنیو اتباعو لپاره د دولتي مرستو د لاسرسي په اړه وروستۍ مقرره خپره کړې. دا مقرره د "دولت پر متکي کسانو" په تعریف کې بدلون راولي او د بایډن ادارې لخوا د قانوني مهاجرت سیسټم د بیا رغولو ژمنه منعکس کوي. د کورني امنیت وزیر وايي، دا مقرره د قانوني مهاجرینو او د هغوی د کورنیو غړو سره عادلانه او انساني چلند تضمینوي. دغه مقرره به د دسمبر په 23، 2022 کې نافذ شي.

O Departamento de Segurança Interna dos EUA (DHS) publicou uma nova regra que esclarece como o encargo público será avaliado para imigrantes. A regra restaura a interpretação histórica, que excluía a consideração de certos benefícios públicos suplementares, como o Medicaid e assistência nutricional, na determinação de inadmissibilidade. Essa ação visa garantir um tratamento justo e humano para imigrantes legais e suas famílias, alinhado aos valores americanos, conforme declarado pelo Secretário Alejandro N. Mayorkas.

A regra define que um não-cidadão pode ser considerado inadmissível se for provável que se torne um encargo público, ou seja, dependente do governo para sua subsistência. A determinação levará em conta a idade, saúde, situação familiar, bens, recursos financeiros, educação e competências do indivíduo, além de uma declaração juramentada de apoio, se aplicável. O recebimento de programas como SSI, TANF, assistência geral ou institucionalização a longo prazo às custas do governo serão considerados.

No entanto, o DHS não considerará benefícios recebidos por outros membros da família que não sejam o requerente, nem o recebimento de certos benefícios não pecuniários como SNAP, CHIP, Medicaid (exceto para institucionalização a longo prazo), benefícios de moradia, vacinas, testes de doenças transmissíveis ou outros benefícios suplementares.

O DHS fornecerá atualizações e realizará ações de conscientização para garantir a aplicação justa da regra e minimizar a confusão. A regra entrará em vigor em 23 de dezembro de 2022.

Ito ay isang buod ng isang anunsyo mula sa Department of Homeland Security (DHS) ng Estados Unidos na naglalabas ng isang bagong patakaran tungkol sa "public charge" na mga tuntunin para sa mga dayuhan. Ang bagong patakaran, na magiging epektibo sa Disyembre 23, 2022, ay ibinabalik ang dating pag-unawa sa kung ano ang ibig sabihin ng "public charge," na nag-aalis ng ilang mga benepisyo sa kalusugan at nutrisyon mula sa pagiging batayan para sa hindi pagtanggap. Layunin nitong tiyakin ang patas at makataong pagtrato sa mga legal na imigrante at ibalik ang tiwala sa sistema ng imigrasyon. Ang pagpapasya kung ang isang dayuhan ay magiging public charge ay ibabatay sa kanilang edad, kalusugan, estado ng pamilya, yaman, at edukasyon, kasama ang pagsumite ng patunay ng suporta at ang kanilang kasaysayan ng pagtanggap ng ilang cash assistance. Hindi isasaalang-alang ang pagtanggap ng mga benepisyo ng kapamilya at ilang partikular na non-cash benefits tulad ng SNAP at Medicaid (maliban sa long-term institutional care). Maglalabas ang DHS ng mas malinaw na gabay at makikipag-ugnayan sa publiko upang maiwasan ang kalituhan.

Міністерство внутрішньої безпеки США (DHS) опублікувало остаточне правило, яке відновлює історичне визначення поняття "суспільний тягар" для іммігрантів. Це правило скасовує політику попередньої адміністрації, яка враховувала отримання певних медичних пільг (наприклад, Medicaid) при визначенні, чи може іммігрант стати "суспільним тягарем".

Нове правило визначає "суспільний тягар" як особу, яка, ймовірно, буде в основному залежати від держави для забезпечення свого існування. При цьому враховуватимуться такі фактори, як вік, стан здоров'я, сімейний стан, активи, освіта та навички. Однак, певні негрошові пільги, такі як Програма додаткової допомоги у харчуванні (SNAP), дитяче медичне страхування (CHIP), Medicaid (окрім довгострокового перебування у стаціонарі) та пільги на житло, не будуть враховуватися.

Метою цього правила є забезпечення справедливого та гуманного ставлення до легальних іммігрантів та членів їхніх сімей, а також відновлення довіри до імміграційної системи. Нове правило набуде чинності 23 грудня 2022 року.

امریکی محکمہ برائے ملکی سالمیت (DHS) نے ایک نیا اصول جاری کیا ہے جو غیر شہریوں کے لیے "پبلک چارج" کے تعین کے نظام کو واضح اور منظم کرتا ہے۔ یہ اصول 2019 کے اس اصول کو منسوخ کرتا ہے جس میں میڈیکیڈ اور غذائی معاونت جیسے فوائد پر غور کیا جاتا تھا۔ نیا اصول 1999 کی رہنمائی کو بحال کرتا ہے، جس میں صرف ان افراد کو عوامی چارج سمجھا جائے گا جو بنیادی طور پر حکومت پر انحصار کرنے کا امکان رکھتے ہیں۔ عمر، صحت، خاندان کی حیثیت، اثاثے، اور تعلیم جیسے عوامل کو مدنظر رکھا جائے گا۔ تاہم، SNAP، CHIP، میڈیکیڈ (طویل مدتی دیکھ بھال کے علاوہ)، اور دیگر مخصوص فوائد پر غور نہیں کیا جائے گا۔ یہ اصول 23 دسمبر 2022 سے نافذ العمل ہوگا۔ DHS اس اصول کے نفاذ کے لیے پالیسی ہدایات کو اپ ڈیٹ کرے گا اور عوام کو آگاہ کرنے کے لیے سرگرمیاں منعقد کرے گا۔

Bộ An ninh Nội địa Hoa Kỳ (DHS) đã ban hành quy định mới về "gánh nặng xã hội" nhằm đảm bảo cách tiếp cận công bằng và nhân đạo đối với người nhập cư. Quy định này khôi phục nguyên tắc lịch sử, không coi các phúc lợi y tế công cộng như Medicaid và chương trình hỗ trợ dinh dưỡng là yếu tố quyết định việc từ chối nhập cư. Bộ trưởng Alejandro N. Mayorkas nhấn mạnh quy định này thể hiện cam kết đối với các giá trị cốt lõi của Hoa Kỳ, không trừng phạt người nhập cư tìm kiếm sự hỗ trợ. Giám đốc Ur M. Jaddou cho biết chính sách này đối xử với mọi người một cách công bằng và tôn trọng, đồng thời cam kết phá bỏ rào cản trong hệ thống nhập cư.

Theo Đạo luật Di trú và Nhập tịch (INA), người nhập cư có thể bị từ chối nếu họ có khả năng trở thành "gánh nặng xã hội". Trước năm 2019, hầu hết các phúc lợi không dùng tiền mặt đều không được tính vào yếu tố này. Quy định mới, có hiệu lực từ ngày 23 tháng 12 năm 2022, sẽ dựa trên các yếu tố như tuổi tác, sức khỏe, tình trạng gia đình, tài sản, nguồn lực, trình độ học vấn, kỹ năng, khả năng nhận các khoản hỗ trợ tiền mặt trực tiếp (như SSI, TANF) và việc nộp Bản Tuyên thệ Hỗ trợ.

DHS sẽ chỉ xem xét phúc lợi nhận được của người nộp đơn, không tính của người thân, và sẽ không tính các phúc lợi không dùng tiền mặt như SNAP, CHIP, Medicaid (trừ trợ giúp dài hạn), phúc lợi nhà ở, các dịch vụ liên quan đến tiêm chủng và xét nghiệm bệnh truyền nhiễm. DHS cũng sẽ cập nhật Cẩm nang Chính sách và tiến hành các hoạt động cộng đồng để giải thích rõ ràng về quy định này.

USCIS is temporarily increasing the automatic extension period for certain Employment Authorization Documents (EADs) from 180 days to up to 540 days. This measure aims to prevent work-authorized noncitizens from experiencing lapses in their employment authorization while their renewal applications are processed, ensuring continuity for employers. The rule applies to eligible applicants who filed or will file their renewal applications within specific periods. This initiative is part of USCIS's broader efforts to reduce EAD processing times and improve access to work permits. USCIS is also seeking public feedback for potential long-term solutions.

This document outlines USCIS's procedures for handling expedite requests for immigration benefits. USCIS considers all requests on a case-by-case basis, requiring documentation to support claims. Expedite criteria include severe financial loss, emergencies or urgent humanitarian situations, benefits for nonprofit organizations serving U.S. cultural or social interests, government interests, and clear USCIS errors. The document also details how to request expedited processing and factors that may impact USCIS's ability to expedite. Numerous updates are listed, indicating revisions to terminology and policy guidance over time.

This document outlines USCIS procedures for handling feedback, complaints, misconduct, and discrimination.

**Feedback:** USCIS collects feedback through surveys after interactions with the Contact Center, by allowing individuals to speak to supervisors during in-person appointments, and via an optional website survey. They also use usability testing and focus groups for website improvements.

**Complaints:** Complaints can be submitted by speaking to a supervisor in USCIS offices, through written correspondence (letters, emails, faxes), directly to the DHS Office of Inspector General (OIG), or by contacting USCIS Headquarters. Dissatisfied callers to the Contact Center can request to speak to a supervisor. USCIS emphasizes that all complaints must be handled appropriately, with a written or verbal response explaining actions taken or expected resolution timelines. Complaints about the unauthorized practice of immigration law are directed to USCIS's website for state-specific reporting information.

**Misconduct:** USCIS employees and contractors are subject to reporting requirements for known or suspected misconduct. This includes fraud, corruption, bribery, sexual misconduct, theft, perjury, physical assault, unauthorized release of information, drug use, misuse of databases or official positions, misuse of government property or cards, falsification of documents, and more. Allegations should be reported promptly to a USCIS supervisor, USCIS Office of Investigations (OI), or DHS OIG. Discriminatory conduct can also be reported to the DHS Office for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties (CRCL). USCIS OI aims to maintain confidentiality but may need to disclose information during disciplinary actions.

**Discrimination:** USCIS prohibits all forms of discriminatory treatment, including retaliation against those who report or participate in discrimination investigations. This policy applies to all interactions, regardless of whether the protected class is specifically defined by federal law. Training is provided to employees on the anti-discrimination policy. Allegations of discrimination (based on race, ethnicity, religion, sex, sexual orientation, disability, etc.) should be reported promptly to a USCIS supervisor, DHS CRCL, USCIS OI, or DHS OIG. Physical assault allegations should be reported to OI or DHS OIG.

**Fraud, Abuse, and Scams:** Information on reporting fraud, abuse, and scams is available on the USCIS Contact Us page. Other avenues for reporting immigration fraud include ICE, the Department of Labor's Wage and Hour Division, the Federal Trade Commission, and state authorities. The USCIS website also provides information on common scams.

**Updates:** The document also lists several technical and policy updates to the USCIS Policy Manual, including changes related to website conformity, terminology ("alien" vs. "noncitizen"), fee schedule alignment, and incorporation of Adjudicator's Field Manual content.

This document outlines USCIS's signature requirements for applications, petitions, and other documents. A valid signature signifies the signer's knowledge, approval, and certification of the document's truthfulness under penalty of perjury. While most benefit requestors must sign their own documents, exceptions exist for minors (under 14), mentally incompetent individuals, and incapacitated adults signing under a durable power of attorney. Corporations and legal entities require authorized signatories, such as executive officers or managing partners. The document also details acceptable and unacceptable signature types, emphasizing that typed names, stamps, and signatures by unauthorized representatives are not valid. It also clarifies that while a Form G-28 indicates authorization to represent, it does not permit the representative to sign other documents on behalf of the client. The document also includes a list of resources and updates regarding policy changes.

Chapter 5 of the USCIS Policy Manual outlines the requirements for interpreters and preparers of benefit requests. If an interpreter assists a benefit requestor, they must provide their contact information and sign and date the request. Similarly, preparers must also provide their contact information and sign and date the request. If an attorney or accredited representative acts as a preparer, they must determine if a Notice of Entry of Appearance (Form G-28) is required. Attorneys and accredited representatives cannot serve as interpreters during interviews.

The chapter also lists various resources, including relevant U.S. Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) sections, Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) provisions, public laws, and specific USCIS forms. There are no appendices currently available.

Recent updates to the Policy Manual include technical changes related to terminology ("noncitizen" vs. "alien," "foreign national" vs. "alien"), revisions to align with fee schedule changes, and the incorporation of Adjudicator's Field Manual (AFM) content. These updates affect various volumes of the Policy Manual, particularly those concerning general policies, nonimmigrants, immigrants, admissibility, employment authorization, and citizenship.

This document outlines the purpose and background of biometric data collection by USCIS. Biometrics, including fingerprints, photographs, and signatures, are collected to verify identity, ensure eligibility for immigration benefits, and protect national security through background checks. The legal authorities for this collection are detailed, along with references to relevant regulations and statutes. The document also lists available resources and notes recent updates to the USCIS Policy Manual regarding terminology and the incorporation of previous guidance.

This document outlines USCIS procedures for biometric data collection. It covers:

*   **Biometric Services Appointments:** How USCIS schedules appointments at Application Support Centers (ASCs), what applicants need to bring, and the consequences of failing to appear or reschedule. It details acceptable reasons for rescheduling, such as illness or transportation issues, and how to submit requests.
*   **Mobile Biometrics Collection:** Describes USCIS's service to collect biometrics outside of ASCs for individuals with disabilities, health reasons, or those in remote locations. It clarifies that USCIS has sole discretion in providing this service and that it is not available for individuals in custody.
*   **Fingerprint Waivers:** Explains the conditions under which a fingerprint requirement can be waived due to a medical condition. It outlines the approval process, situations where waivers are not granted, and the requirements for individuals who receive a waiver.
*   **Biometrics Collected:** Briefly mentions that fingerprints, photographs, and signatures are collected. It notes that photographs are embedded in secure documents and that USCIS may issue a Request for Evidence if a photograph is not submitted with an application.
*   **Resources and Updates:** Lists relevant regulations and provides information on updates to the USCIS Policy Manual concerning biometric collection procedures, terminology changes, and the incorporation of previous guidance.

This document is Chapter 1 of the USCIS Policy Manual, focusing on the Purpose and Background of adjudicating immigration benefit requests. It outlines that USCIS's primary role is to review these requests for jurisdiction, documentation, existing files, and eligibility. The chapter details the legal authorities governing this process, including the Homeland Security Act of 2002, the Federal Records Act, the Privacy Act, the Freedom of Information Act, and various sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) and Code of Federal Regulations (CFR). It also lists available resources and describes recent updates to the manual, including terminology changes (e.g., "noncitizen" to "alien") and the incorporation of previous Adjudicator's Field Manual (AFM) content into the Policy Manual. The chapter emphasizes that while general guidance is provided, specific procedures may vary depending on the type of benefit requested.

This chapter, "Record of Proceeding," defines a record of proceeding as the official documentation of any application, petition, hearing, or other USCIS action. These records are typically found within Alien Registration Files (A-Files) or other agency files, which can be physical, digital, or a hybrid. A-Files document an individual's immigration history and are maintained by DHS for those born within the last 100 years, with older files transferred to the National Archives and Records Administration (NARA). The chapter also notes several technical updates to the Policy Manual, including changes in terminology ("noncitizen" vs. "alien," "foreign national" vs. "alien") and the ongoing incorporation of Adjudicator's Field Manual (AFM) content into the USCIS Policy Manual.

Chapter 4 of the USCIS Policy Manual, titled "Burden and Standards of Proof," outlines the responsibilities and evidence requirements for immigration benefit requests.

**Burden of Proof:**
*   The **benefit requestor** always bears the burden of proof to establish eligibility for an immigration benefit.
*   This burden **never shifts to USCIS**.
*   Once the requestor meets their initial burden, they have made a **prima facie case**, demonstrating minimum eligibility.

**Standards of Proof:**
*   The **standard of proof** refers to the amount of evidence needed.
*   The most common standard in immigration proceedings is the **preponderance of the evidence**. This means the evidence must show the claim is "probably true" or "more likely than not" (greater than 50% probability).
*   If this standard is not met, USCIS may request more evidence or deny the case.
*   Some applications require a **higher standard**, such as "clear and convincing evidence," as specified by law (e.g., marriage during removal proceedings, determining citizenship of children born out of wedlock).

The document also lists relevant **Resources**, notes the absence of **Appendices**, and details several **Updates** to the Policy Manual, primarily concerning terminology changes (e.g., "noncitizen" vs. "alien," "foreign national") and the incorporation of previous Adjudicator's Field Manual content.

Chapter 9 of the USCIS Policy Manual, titled "Rendering a Decision," outlines the procedures for approving or denying benefit requests.

**Approvals:** If a requestor meets all eligibility requirements after proper filing, an officer may approve the request and update relevant systems.

**Denials:** If a requestor is found ineligible, the officer denies the request, updates systems, and issues a written decision explaining the reasons. This decision should be in plain language and include appeal/motion guidance.

There are three types of denials:

1.  **Lack of Legal Basis:** If a request has no legal basis for approval and no further evidence could establish one, it should be denied without an RFE or NOID.
2.  **Abandonment:** A request is denied as abandoned if the requestor fails to attend a required interview/appointment or provide requested evidence. This denial is without prejudice for refiling, but the original priority/processing date cannot be applied to a new request.
3.  **Discretionary Denials:** For benefits requiring a favorable exercise of discretion (assessed after eligibility is met), an officer reviews all case facts. Discretion cannot be exercised arbitrarily. A discretionary denial will explain the reasons.

The document also lists relevant resources, appendices (none currently available), and recent updates to the Policy Manual, including technical changes to terminology and the incorporation of previous Adjudicator's Field Manual content.

This document outlines the purpose, background, and legal basis for U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) flexibilities during emergencies or unforeseen circumstances. It explains that USCIS may, at its discretion, implement measures to assist immigration benefit requestors facing challenges such as obtaining documentation, responding to notices, appearing for appointments, or dealing with economic hardship due to events like natural disasters, public health emergencies, or terrorist attacks. The document also references relevant legal authorities and notes ongoing updates to the USCIS Policy Manual, including changes in terminology and the integration of previous Adjudicator's Field Manual content.

This document outlines USCIS flexibilities during emergencies or unforeseen circumstances like natural disasters, national emergencies, or conflicts abroad. These flexibilities allow USCIS to address challenges faced by benefit requestors, potentially including delays in filing, fee waivers, document replacement, rescheduling, parole, expedited processing, and extensions for Visa Waiver Program entrants.

The document details various immigration policy flexibilities for:
- **Nonimmigrants in the U.S.:** This includes excusing late filings for extensions of stay or changes of status due to extraordinary circumstances, providing satisfactory departure for Visa Waiver Program entrants, and allowing for adjustment of status even if lawful status was not continuously maintained due to no fault of the applicant. Reinstatement to student status is also discussed.
- **Parolees:** The possibility of re-parole for urgent humanitarian reasons or significant public benefit is mentioned.
- **Travel Documents:** Expedited or emergency issuance of travel documents for those needing to depart and return to the U.S. due to emergencies.
- **Deferred Action:** This prosecutorial discretion may be granted to defer removal actions, considering emergencies that prevent departure.
- **F-1 Students:** Employment authorization may be granted for students facing severe economic hardship due to unforeseen circumstances.
- **Document Replacement:** Procedures for replacing lost, damaged, or incorrect USCIS-issued documents.
- **Conditional Permanent Residents:** Officers may excuse late filings for petitions to remove conditions on residence if there's good cause, such as an emergency.
- **Failure to Respond to Notices:** USCIS may delay adjudication after a Request for Evidence (RFE) or Notice of Intent to Deny (NOID) due to emergencies, allowing for submission of additional evidence. Alternative means of demonstrating eligibility may be considered, and denials may be reopened.
- **Motions to Reopen and Appeals:** Failure to file these within the specified timelines may be excused if due to emergencies or unforeseen circumstances.
- **Fee Waivers and Exemptions:** Individuals impacted by emergencies may qualify for fee waivers or exemptions.
- **Expedited Processing:** Requests for expedited adjudication may be granted based on emergencies or urgent humanitarian situations.

The document also covers the **burden of proof** for benefit requestors, noting that USCIS may exercise discretion in evaluating evidence during emergencies. For **aliens outside the United States**, assistance may be provided through humanitarian or significant public benefit parole, and for lawful permanent residents or others needing travel documentation to return to the U.S.

Finally, it lists **resources**, notes the absence of forms and appendices, and details **updates** to the Policy Manual regarding terminology changes and incorporation of Adjudicator's Field Manual content.

This document outlines USCIS's operational responses to emergencies or unforeseen circumstances that may disrupt its facilities or public services. The response strategy is tailored based on several factors, generally including reporting, public notification, and activation of local emergency procedures.

When a public-facing facility is closed or USCIS systems are impaired due to an emergency, USCIS announces the closure on its website and social media. They also attempt to directly contact individuals with appointments and notify media contacts. Signage and updated phone/email messages are used to inform the public, and procedures are in place for safe evacuation if a closure occurs during business hours.

If a facility remains open during an emergency, USCIS may offer to reschedule appointments, especially if disruptions affect mail service or housing.

In certain situations, USCIS staff may activate local emergency response procedures, evacuate facilities, and coordinate with first responders and other government entities. Impacted field offices can be activated as emergency response centers to assist the affected population with immigration matters, including providing temporary status documentation, biometrics processing, and citizenship verification.

The document also lists resources, appendices (none available), and updates, including technical revisions to terminology (e.g., "noncitizen" to "alien") and the incorporation of Adjudicator's Field Manual content into the USCIS Policy Manual.

This document, Chapter 1 of the USCIS Policy Manual, outlines the purpose and background of employment authorization for aliens in the United States. It explains that aliens must obtain authorization to work legally, as working without it can lead to severe immigration consequences. Some aliens are automatically authorized based on their status, while others must apply for an Employment Authorization Document (EAD) using Form I-765.

The chapter details the historical context, referencing the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 (IRCA), which aimed to curb illegal immigration by penalizing employers who knowingly hire unauthorized workers. IRCA introduced the Employment Eligibility Verification (Form I-9) to ensure all employees can prove their legal right to work. Employers use this form to verify identity and authorization, with some utilizing E-Verify for electronic checks. The EAD was created to serve as evidence of work authorization for specific alien classes.

Legal authorities cited include the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) sections 103 and 274A, and federal regulations 8 CFR 274a Subpart B. The "Resources" section lists relevant forms and legal references, while "Appendices" are noted as unavailable. The "Updates" section highlights recent technical changes to terminology within the Policy Manual, specifically regarding the terms "alien," "noncitizen," and "foreign national," and mentions new policy guidance on discretionary employment authorization for certain categories like pending adjustment of status or deferred action cases.

This document outlines the eligibility requirements for aliens seeking employment authorization in the United States. It categorizes eligibility into three main classes: authorization for any employer, authorization for a specific employer, and authorization upon USCIS approval.

**Aliens Authorized to Work for Any Employer Based on Status or Circumstances:**

*   **Must Apply for Documentation:** Certain aliens, including refugees, certain Afghan and Ukrainian parolees, K-1/K-2 visa holders, parents/children of LPRs from international organizations, Palauan citizens, those granted withholding of deportation, aliens under Deferred Enforced Departure (DED), Temporary Protected Status (TPS) recipients, Family Unity Program beneficiaries, V nonimmigrants, and CNMI residents, must apply to USCIS for an Employment Authorization Document (EAD) using Form I-765.
*   **Do Not Need to Apply:** Lawful permanent residents (LPRs), lawful temporary residents, asylees, citizens of Micronesia or the Marshall Islands, K-3/K-4 visa holders, victims of severe trafficking (T-1), spouses of principal E nonimmigrants, spouses of principal L-1 nonimmigrants, and victims of qualifying criminal activity (U-1) and their family members (U-2 to U-5) generally do not need to apply for an EAD as their existing documentation serves as proof of authorization. However, they must still present acceptable documents for identity and employment authorization. Specific documentation requirements are outlined for LPRs and others who may use their Form I-94.

**Aliens Authorized to Work for a Specific Employer Based on Status or Circumstances:**

*   This category includes various nonimmigrants and parolees who automatically receive work authorization incident to their status for a specific employer. Examples include foreign government officials, treaty traders/investors, certain students (F-1) with specific employment types (on-campus, CPT, STEM OPT, H-1B extension), representatives of international organizations, temporary workers (H-1, H-2, H-3), representatives of foreign media, exchange visitors (J-1), intra-company transferees (L-1), aliens of extraordinary ability (O-1), athletes/artists/entertainers (P-1 to P-3), cultural exchange visitors (Q-1), religious workers (R-1), NATO civilian employees, USMCA professionals (TN), temporary workers with filed petitions, CNMI investors/workers, "nonimmigrant treaty aliens" in specialty occupations (E-3), and entrepreneurs paroled. These individuals do not need to file Form I-765 but are restricted to employment with the specified employer.

**Aliens Required to Apply for Employment Authorization:**

*   This group is not automatically authorized to work and must apply to USCIS for an EAD. This includes spouses/dependents of foreign government officials (A-1/A-2) with State Department endorsement, spouses/dependents of TECRO employees (E-1), F-1 students seeking pre-completion OPT, STEM OPT extensions, employment sponsorship by international organizations, or those facing severe economic hardship. It also includes spouses/dependents of international organization representatives (G-1, G-3, G-4), spouses/minor children of exchange visitors (J-2), M-1 students seeking practical training, dependents of NATO-1 to NATO-6 nonimmigrants, asylum applicants, adjustment of status applicants (INA 245), cancellation of removal applicants, most parolees (with specific exceptions), spouses of CNMI investors (E-2), aliens granted deferred action, registry applicants, certain B-1 visitors (personal/domestic servants, foreign airline employees), applicants with final deportation/removal orders, applicants with pending TPS, special agricultural worker applicants, witnesses/informants (S nonimmigrants), legalization applicants (INA 245A), LIFE Act applicants, derivative T visa family members, spouses of certain H-1B nonimmigrants, VAWA self-petitioners, spouses of entrepreneur parolees, and principal beneficiaries of approved I-140 facing compelling circumstances and their dependents. Upon approval of Form I-765, their employment is generally unrestricted.

The document also includes sections on Resources, Appendices, and Updates, with the latter detailing recent technical changes and policy clarifications regarding terminology (alien vs. noncitizen), EAD validity periods for various categories, and the use of Form I-94 for employment authorization.

Chapter 4 of the USCIS Policy Manual, "Adjudication," details the process for reviewing and deciding on Applications for Employment Authorization (Form I-765). Upon acceptance, USCIS verifies the applicant's identity, immigration status, and eligibility for employment authorization. This includes checking for proper fee payment, fee waivers, or exemptions. If the eligibility category is unclear, USCIS may issue a Request for Evidence (RFE).

Key aspects of the adjudication process include:

*   **General Review:** USCIS ensures the application is complete and all required initial evidence is submitted.
*   **Identity and Eligibility Verification:** These are common to all eligibility categories. Identity is verified, potentially requiring biometrics. Eligibility is confirmed by verifying the applicant meets the requirements of a specific category and has submitted supporting documents such as visas, Form I-94, or approval notices.
*   **Discretionary Factors:** In many cases, especially those under 8 CFR 274a.12(c), employment authorization is granted at USCIS's discretion. Negative factors, such as supporting terrorist organizations, are considered overwhelmingly negative in discretionary analyses.
*   **Decision:**
    *   **Approval:** If identity and eligibility are established, and discretion is favorably exercised, the application is approved, and an Employment Authorization Document (EAD) is issued. The EAD itself does not grant immigration status but serves as proof of work authorization. Validity periods are determined by the eligibility category and may coincide with the applicant's underlying immigration status.
    *   **Denial:** If identity cannot be verified, eligibility is not established, or the application is abandoned, USCIS denies the application and provides written notification of the reasons. There is no appeal, but a motion to reopen or reconsider can be filed.
*   **Early Filing:** Renewals filed more than 180 days before expiration are generally not backdated or postdated.
*   **Automatic Termination and Revocation:** Employment authorization can terminate automatically if eligibility ceases. Revocation requires a notice of intent to revoke (NOIR) if the application contained false statements, terms were violated, the basis for the EAD is no longer valid, or the approval was an error.
*   **Withdrawing Application:** Applicants can withdraw their Form I-765 in writing before a final decision.
*   **Motion to Reopen or Reconsider:** A motion to reopen or reconsider can be filed using Form I-290B within 30 days of denial.
*   **Effect of Motion/Appeal:** Eligibility for employment authorization is generally maintained if an underlying application is still pending or if a timely appeal or motion to reopen is filed and remains pending.

The chapter also includes tables detailing various eligibility categories (under 8 CFR 274a.12) and their associated maximum initial and renewal validity periods, as well as resources, appendices (none available), and updates to policy guidance. Recent updates focus on discretionary analysis, validity periods for specific categories like refugees and asylees, and the use of Form I-94 as evidence.

This chapter, titled "Reserved," focuses on guidance, resources, and updates related to U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) policies, particularly concerning employment authorization for aliens. It lists relevant regulations (8 CFR 274a Subpart B, 8 CFR 274a.12, INA 103, INA 274A), forms (G-28, I-765, I-9), and USCIS resources. The chapter also details several technical updates to the USCIS Policy Manual, including changes in terminology (e.g., "noncitizen" to "alien" and vice-versa), clarification of employment authorization for specific categories like adjustment of status and deferred action, and the removal of an exemption from discretion for asylum applicants seeking employment authorization, with a note about a preliminary injunction affecting certain asylum seekers. It also highlights the consolidation of policy guidance on discretionary analysis for benefit requests, including employment authorization.

This document outlines USCIS policies and procedures related to employment authorization for aliens. It details various resources, including relevant regulations (8 CFR 274a, INA 103, INA 274A), forms (G-1055, G-28, I-765, I-9), and guidance on using the USCIS Policy Manual.

Key updates and clarifications include:

*   **Discretionary Analysis:** USCIS is updating guidance on factors considered for discretionary benefit requests, including parole history and involvement with anti-American or terrorist organizations.
*   **EAD Validity Periods:** Policy is being updated regarding maximum validity periods for Employment Authorization Documents (EADs) for various categories, including refugees, asylees, parolees, and those with pending applications for asylum, adjustment of status, or removal proceedings. The I-94 form is clarified as acceptable proof of status and employment authorization for certain categories.
*   **F-1 Student Employment:** Guidance is provided for F-1 students experiencing severe economic hardship due to emergent circumstances (special student relief).
*   **E and L Spouse Employment:** Clarification is offered on documentation acceptable as evidence of employment authorization incident to status for E and L spouses.
*   **Technical Updates:** Several technical updates have occurred, including the consistent use of "alien" or "noncitizen" throughout the Policy Manual and the removal of the exemption from discretion for asylum applicants seeking employment authorization (effective August 25, 2020), with a note about a limited injunctive relief for certain CASA and ASAP members.
*   **Consolidation of Guidance:** Existing policy guidance on discretionary analysis for certain benefit requests, including employment authorization applications, is being consolidated.

The document also lists the structure of the USCIS Policy Manual, specifically Volume 10, which covers Employment Authorization and includes chapters on Purpose and Background, Eligibility Requirements, Documentation and Evidence, Adjudication, and Reserved sections.

This document outlines the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) policy regarding employment authorization for various categories of aliens. It references the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) and DHS regulations (8 CFR 274a.12) which categorize aliens into three main groups for employment authorization: those authorized incident to status, those authorized for a specific employer, and those requiring discretionary application. The document also details the process for applying for an Employment Authorization Document (EAD, Form I-765) and lists relevant resources and updates to the USCIS Policy Manual, including changes in terminology and specific guidance on automatic employment authorization extensions for H-4, E, and L dependent spouses, and discretionary employment authorization based on pending adjustment of status or deferred action.

As of November 12, 2021, certain dependent spouses of E-1, E-2, E-3, and L-2 nonimmigrants are considered employment authorized incident to their status. They can obtain an Employment Authorization Document (EAD) by filing Form I-765. New Class of Admission (COA) codes (E-1S, E-2S, E-3S, L-2S) on their Form I-94, issued from January 30, 2022, onwards, serve as evidence of this authorization. For Forms I-94 issued before this date, a USCIS notice combined with the I-94 showing specific nonimmigrant statuses (E-1, E-2, E-3, E-3D, E-3R, or L-2) is acceptable as proof of employment authorization.

E and L spouses can still apply for an EAD. The validity period of an EAD is generally aligned with the Form I-94 expiration date, not exceeding two years for E and L spouses, or three years for H-4 spouses.

For E, L, and H-4 dependent spouses, their EAD is automatically extended for up to 180 days if they filed a renewal application (Form I-765) before their current EAD expired and have an unexpired Form I-94 indicating valid derivative status. This automatic extension ends if their nonimmigrant status expires, their renewal application is approved or denied, or 180 days pass from their previous EAD's expiration. The automatic extension is evidenced by the expired EAD (with specific categories), a Notice of Action for Form I-765 showing timely filing, and an unexpired Form I-94. Reverification is needed at the end of the extension period.

Note that this policy does not apply to spouses of TECRO/TECO employees, E-2 CNMI Investors, or spouses of E-2 CNMI investors with a Foreign Retiree Investment Certificate.

This document outlines USCIS policy regarding employment authorization for certain employment-based immigrants facing compelling circumstances. It details eligibility requirements, defines what constitutes compelling circumstances (including serious illness, employer disputes, substantial harm, and significant employer disruption), and explains the validity and renewal process for such Employment Authorization Documents (EADs). The policy also covers eligibility for spouses and children, the period of authorized stay granted, and how it affects accrual of unlawful presence. The document is organized into sections covering eligibility, definitions of compelling circumstances, validity periods, dependent eligibility, renewal procedures, and authorized stay, with accompanying resources and updates.

Chapter 4 of the USCIS Policy Manual is currently reserved. The "Resources" section lists key regulations and forms related to employment authorization, including 8 CFR 274a.12 and 274a.13, AR-11, G-1055, G-28, I-765, and I-9, along with a guide on using the USCIS Policy Manual website. There are no appendices available at this time.

The "Updates" section details several technical revisions to the Policy Manual. These updates include replacing terms like "noncitizen," "alien," and "foreign national" with other appropriate terms, such as "alien" or "noncitizen," depending on the specific update, to refer to individuals who are not U.S. citizens or nationals. These changes have been applied across various volumes of the USCIS Policy Manual, specifically mentioning Volumes 1, 2, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, and 12.

Additionally, USCIS has updated policy guidance to increase the validity period for employment authorization for individuals applying for adjustment of status under INA Section 245. Further guidance has been provided regarding discretionary employment authorization applications, specifically for those with pending adjustment of status applications (8 CFR 274a.12(c)(9)) or grants of deferred action (8 CFR 274a.12(c)(14)), and outlines the categories of aliens eligible for such authorization. These updates are reflected in sections 10 USCIS-PM A-Part A and 10 USCIS-PM B-Part B.

This document outlines U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) policy guidance related to employment authorization. It includes sections on Resources, Appendices, and Updates. The Resources section lists relevant regulations and forms such as 8 CFR 204.5(p), 8 CFR 274a Subpart B, I-765, and I-9. The Updates section details several policy changes and technical updates. Key updates include:

*   Issuing guidance on eligibility criteria for employment authorization in compelling circumstances.
*   Updating guidance on documentation for H-4, E, and L dependent spouses to evidence employment authorization incident to their status.
*   Issuing guidance on automatic extensions of employment authorization for certain H-4, E, and L nonimmigrant dependent spouses, and rescinding a 2002 INS memorandum.
*   Rescinding policy guidance on discretionary employment authorization for parolees.
*   Updating policy guidance to increase the validity period of employment authorization for applicants seeking adjustment of status.
*   Providing policy guidance on discretionary employment authorization for pending adjustment of status applications and deferred action grants, and outlining eligible categories.
*   Updating policies on the exercise of discretion for employment authorization for paroled foreign nationals.

The document also references specific chapters within the USCIS Policy Manual, primarily Volume 10, concerning Employment Authorization, with a focus on specific categories like H-4, E, and L dependent spouses, and employment-based immigrants in compelling circumstances.

The USCIS Policy Manual, Part A, focuses on Secure Identity Documents, outlining policies and procedures. It includes resources such as regulations (8 CFR 103.16, 103.2, 103.8), fee schedules, and various USCIS application forms (I-131, I-131A, I-765, I-912, N-565). The manual also provides guidance on using the USCIS Policy Manual website.

Recent updates to the Policy Manual include clarifications on:
*   **Gender Recognition:** USCIS recognizes two biological sexes (male/female) for benefit requests and documents, but also allows individuals to select their gender on forms without documentation, with issued documents reflecting their selection.
*   **Terminology:** Revisions to replace terms like "noncitizen" and "foreign national" with "alien" or other appropriate terms, and vice-versa in separate updates.
*   **Form I-131 Name:** Updating the name of Form I-131 to align with its current edition.
*   **Legal Name Determination:** Guidance on how officers determine a benefit requestor's legal name.
*   **Fee Schedule Alignment:** Revisions to align with the Fee Schedule and Changes to Certain Other Immigration Benefit Request Requirements Final Rule.
*   **Adjudicator's Field Manual (AFM) Content:** Incorporation of AFM content into the USCIS Policy Manual, with the Policy Manual prevailing in case of conflicts.
*   **Permanent Resident Card Reissuance:** Clarification that Form I-90 is always required for replacement or reissuance of a Permanent Resident Card.
*   **General Secure Document Policies:** Issuing guidance on general policies and procedures related to secure documents.

The manual is organized into multiple volumes and parts covering various aspects of immigration policies and procedures.

This document, Chapter 1 of the USCIS Policy Manual, details the purpose and background of Lawful Permanent Residents (LPRs) and their Permanent Resident Cards (PRCs), commonly known as "green cards." It explains that LPRs are individuals authorized by the U.S. government to live permanently in the United States and are issued a PRC as proof of their status. LPRs are generally required to carry their PRCs at all times. The document also outlines the historical evolution of alien registration documents, from the Alien Registration Act of 1940 to the modern, technologically advanced PRC. It specifies the use of Form I-90 for replacing a PRC and for certain other situations, such as automatic conversion to permanent resident status or resuming residency after commuter status. Key legal authorities and resources related to LPRs and their cards are listed, and the "Updates" section details recent changes to terminology and the incorporation of Adjudicator's Field Manual content into the USCIS Policy Manual, along with specific updates regarding the issuance of policy guidance for Form I-90.

This document provides guidance on replacing a Permanent Resident Card (PRC). It outlines eligibility requirements, including properly filing Form I-90, establishing identity and lawful permanent resident (LPR) or conditional permanent resident (CPR) status. LPRs in removal proceedings are entitled to evidence of status until ordered removed. CPRs, admitted conditionally due to marriage or investment, receive a 2-year PRC and must file to remove conditions.

The process involves filing Form I-90, paying applicable fees, and potentially attending a biometrics appointment for fingerprinting, signature, and photograph. Temporary evidence of LPR status can be provided via an I-90 receipt notice or an ADIT stamp. Adjudication involves verifying LPR status, conducting security checks, and potentially issuing requests for evidence or interviews. Decisions can result in approval or denial, with options for motions to reopen or reconsider. The document also details the forms and regulations related to PRC replacement and lists recent updates to the policy manual concerning terminology and procedural clarifications.

This document outlines USCIS policies regarding expired Permanent Resident Cards (PRCs). It explains that expired PRCs are generally collected by USCIS offices to prevent fraud and enhance security, unless they are accompanied by an extension sticker or valid receipt notice. Offices that collect expired cards must update systems and destroy them. The document also lists relevant legal resources and details several technical updates to the USCIS Policy Manual, primarily concerning terminology changes like replacing "noncitizen" with "alien" and vice versa, and incorporating previous Adjudicator's Field Manual content. It also clarifies policy updates related to temporary proof of status for LPRs applying for replacement cards and the eligibility requirements for replacing PRCs using Form I-90.

This document outlines the "Commuter Cards" chapter, focusing on the administrative grant of "commuter status" for Lawful Permanent Residents (LPRs) living in Canada or Mexico and commuting to the U.S. for employment. There are two types of commuters: those with regular employment and seasonal workers (present in the U.S. for 6 months or less annually). LPRs use Form I-90 to obtain or remove commuter status and receive a Permanent Resident Card (PRC) indicating this status.

To be eligible for commuter status, individuals must be LPRs, reside in Canada or Mexico, and have had U.S. employment within the six months prior to filing. Evidence of employment can include pay stubs or an employer letter. To remove commuter status, a commuter must demonstrate U.S. residency by providing evidence like a lease or utility bills with Form I-90. Seasonal workers exceeding six months of aggregate U.S. presence annually lose commuter status.

Commuters can lose LPR status if they are out of regular U.S. employment for six continuous months, with exceptions for reasons beyond their control or if they have worked 90 days in the U.S. within the preceding 12 months. The document also lists relevant regulations, forms, and updates to the USCIS Policy Manual, including terminology changes regarding "alien" and "noncitizen" and the incorporation of Adjudicator's Field Manual content.

This document outlines Chapter 1 of the USCIS Policy Manual, focusing on the Purpose and Background of naturalization. It details the USCIS's role in investigating and examining naturalization applicants to ensure they meet all eligibility requirements. This process includes background checks, immigration record reviews, interviews, English and civics testing, and disability exception qualifications. The document also traces the historical evolution of naturalization examinations since 1906 and lists the legal authorities governing these processes. Additionally, it addresses a policy change regarding the citizenship acquisition for children of U.S. military and government employees stationed abroad, and notes several technical updates and revisions to terminology within the Policy Manual concerning terms like "alien" and "noncitizen."

Chapter 2 of the USCIS Policy Manual details the background and security checks required for naturalization applicants. This process includes a comprehensive investigation by USCIS, which involves criminal background and security checks. Key components are fingerprint collection and a "name check" conducted by the FBI. These checks are mandatory for most applicants and must be completed before their naturalization interview.

Fingerprints are collected at a Biometric Service Appointment, and applicants must appear or risk abandoning their application. Previously, individuals 75 and older were exempt, but improved technology now allows for fingerprinting of all ages. Fingerprints are valid for 15 months. Accommodations are available for applicants unable to attend appointments due to disability or hospitalization.

Fingerprint waivers are possible for applicants with specific medical conditions that prevent fingerprinting, but require an in-person assessment by an authorized USCIS officer. If a waiver is granted, applicants must provide local police clearance letters and may need to provide a sworn statement regarding their good moral character. Waivers are not granted solely based on having fewer than 10 fingers, unclassifiable fingerprints, or temporary conditions.

The FBI's "name check" searches various law enforcement files and must be cleared before an interview is scheduled. A "No Record" or "Positive Response" is valid for the application's duration or 15 months if used for other applications.

The Appendices section discusses a policy change regarding the eligibility of children of U.S. military or government employees stationed abroad for citizenship acquisition under INA 320, particularly after the enactment of the Citizenship for Children of Military Members and Civil Servants Act in March 2020.

Updates indicate ongoing revisions to the Policy Manual, including replacing specific terminology like "noncitizen," "alien," and "foreign national" with updated or appropriate terms, and incorporating Adjudicator's Field Manual content. Notably, an update clarifies that all naturalization applicants require biometrics unless they qualify for a medical fingerprint waiver.

This document outlines Chapter 3 of the Naturalization Interview process, detailing the roles and responsibilities of USCIS officers and authorized representatives, as well as the procedures for interpreters. It covers the preliminary review of an applicant's file, including background checks and potential jurisdictional changes. The initial naturalization examination process is described, encompassing the interview, English and civics tests, and documentation review. The chapter also addresses subsequent re-examinations, expedited processing for certain SSI beneficiaries, and provides a list of relevant resources and appendices, including updates to policy manual terminology and guidance on the citizenship of children of U.S. military and government employees stationed abroad.

Chapter 5 of the USCIS Policy Manual covers "Motion to Reopen" for naturalization applications. It details two primary scenarios:

1.  **USCIS Motion to Reopen:** An officer initiates this if disqualifying derogatory information is found after an application is approved but before the Oath of Allegiance, or if the applicant fails to appear for two Oath ceremonies without good cause. The applicant has 15 days to respond. If the applicant overcomes the issues, the motion is denied and the Oath is scheduled. If not, the motion is granted, and the application is denied.

2.  **Motion to Reopen Administratively Closed Application:** An applicant can request to reopen an administratively closed application within one year of closure. No additional fees are required, and the request date serves as the new filing date for eligibility.

The chapter also includes information on resources, appendices regarding the citizenship of children of U.S. military and government employees stationed abroad, and updates related to terminology changes and the integration of Adjudicator's Field Manual content into the Policy Manual.

This document, Chapter 1 of the USCIS Policy Manual, outlines the purpose and background of providing accommodations for naturalization applicants with disabilities.

**Purpose:** USCIS aims to provide equal opportunity for applicants with disabilities to complete the naturalization process through reasonable modifications. While fundamental changes or undue burdens are not required, USCIS evaluates accommodation requests case-by-case, prioritizing the applicant's needs. Accommodations can be requested at any stage of the process.

**Background:** The Rehabilitation Act mandates federal agencies, including USCIS, to provide reasonable accommodations to persons with disabilities in their programs, ensuring equal participation in processes like naturalization.

**Accommodations vs. Waivers:** Accommodations are modifications to existing procedures to help applicants meet requirements, whereas waivers exempt applicants from meeting certain requirements altogether. Accommodations do not waive naturalization obligations but rather change how they are met.

**Legal Authorities:** Key legal frameworks include Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, 29 U.S.C. 794, 6 CFR 15, and 8 CFR 334.4.

**Appendices:** Discusses a policy change regarding children of U.S. armed forces and government employees stationed abroad, clarifying their eligibility for citizenship acquisition under INA 320.

**Updates:** This section details various technical updates to the Policy Manual, including terminology changes (e.g., "alien," "noncitizen," "foreign national"), incorporation of Braille accommodations, and the integration of Adjudicator's Field Manual content.

Chapter 2 of the USCIS Policy Manual outlines accommodation policies and procedures. USCIS has established guidelines for handling accommodation requests, including providing local information, designating points of contact, timely responding to inquiries, establishing internal filing processes, and processing requests appropriately.

**Requesting Accommodations:**
*   Applicants are responsible for requesting accommodations in advance for each needed instance.
*   Requests can be made concurrently with the naturalization application, by contacting the USCIS Contact Center, using the online form, or with a field office at any time during the naturalization process.
*   The timeliness of the request impacts the ability to provide the accommodation. Some accommodations (e.g., speaking loudly) can be immediate, while others (e.g., sign language interpreter, off-site examination) require advance planning.

**Documentation and Evidence:**
*   USCIS evaluates accommodation requests on a case-by-case basis.
*   Documentation of a medical condition is generally not required, but may be needed in rare circumstances.

**Providing Accommodations:**
*   If an accommodation is warranted, it should be provided at the scheduled appointment time, ideally without rescheduling.
*   If an accommodation cannot be provided as scheduled, the applicant must be notified promptly, and the appointment should be rescheduled reasonably.

The chapter also includes **Resources** such as relevant statutes and USCIS forms, **Appendices** detailing a policy change regarding citizenship acquisition for children of U.S. military and government employees stationed abroad, and **Updates** on changes to terminology (e.g., "noncitizen" to "alien," "foreign national" to "alien") and the incorporation of Braille-related accommodations for the naturalization test. It also notes the ongoing process of integrating Adjudicator's Field Manual content into the Policy Manual.

This chapter outlines the accommodations USCIS provides for applicants with disabilities throughout the naturalization process, covering the interview, test, and Oath of Allegiance. Accommodations are determined on a case-by-case basis and can include extending examination time, providing sign language interpreters, allowing relatives or legal guardians to attend, permitting nonverbal communication, and conducting off-site examinations. For the naturalization test, accommodations also include providing reading materials in large print or braille and administering oral writing tests. For the Oath of Allegiance, language can be simplified, scheduling expedited, interpreters provided, or the oath administered off-site. The chapter also includes sections on resources and updates to USCIS policy.

This document, "Chapter 1 - Purpose and Background," outlines the general requirements for U.S. naturalization. It defines naturalization as the conferral of U.S. citizenship after birth. The applicant bears the burden of proof to demonstrate they meet the eligibility criteria.

Key general eligibility requirements for naturalization include:
*   Being 18 years or older at the time of application.
*   Holding Lawful Permanent Resident (LPR) status for at least five years.
*   Maintaining continuous residence in the U.S. as an LPR for five years immediately preceding the application and up to naturalization.
*   Being physically present in the U.S. for at least 30 months within the five years before filing.
*   Residing in the state or USCIS district with jurisdiction for at least three months prior to filing.
*   Demonstrating good moral character for five years before filing and leading up to taking the Oath of Allegiance.
*   Showing attachment to the principles of the U.S. Constitution and being well-disposed to the welfare of the United States.
*   Being able to read, write, speak, and understand English, and possessing knowledge of U.S. history and government.

The chapter also lists relevant legal authorities (INA and CFR sections), resources such as forms and study guides, and discusses historical policy changes regarding the citizenship of children of U.S. military and government employees stationed abroad, specifically referencing amendments to INA 320. Updates to the USCIS Policy Manual concerning terminology, the incorporation of Adjudicator's Field Manual content, and specific policy areas like religious vocations and amendments to section 1059(e) are also noted.

This document outlines the "Continuous Residence" requirement for naturalization in the United States. Key aspects include:

*   **General Requirement:** Applicants generally need to have resided continuously in the U.S. for at least 5 years after becoming a lawful permanent resident (LPR) before filing for naturalization, and also for 3 months in the state or district with jurisdiction. Continuous residence means maintaining a permanent dwelling place.
*   **Breaks in Residence:**
